statement.text: Amputation in Buerger disease (thromboangiitis obliterans) is primarily determined by continued tobacco use, with major amputation rates of 10-25% at 5 years in active smokers reduced to near zero with complete smoking cessation.

explanation.intuition: Buerger disease is unique among vascular diseases because the pathology is directly caused by tobacco exposure. Unlike atherosclerosis where risk factors accelerate disease, in Buerger disease tobacco IS the disease. Remove the tobacco, and the disease stops progressing.
explanation.key_insight: Complete abstinence from ALL tobacco products (including smokeless tobacco, marijuana, and nicotine replacement) is essential. Even a single cigarette can reactivate disease and precipitate amputation. The vascular surgeon's most important intervention is smoking cessation counseling.
explanation.technical_details: Buerger disease affects small and medium vessels of extremities. Revascularization options are severely limited due to distal vessel involvement - no suitable target for bypass in most cases. When amputation is required: (1) Delay amputation as long as possible to allow collateral development; (2) Attempt tissue-sparing levels; (3) Multiple minor amputations (toe, ray) common before major amputation; (4) Healing may be delayed due to poor distal perfusion; (5) Sympathectomy may improve healing and pain. Adjunctive therapies: Iloprost (prostacyclin analog), spinal cord stimulation, hyperbaric oxygen - limited evidence.

amputation_rates.continued_smoking: Major amputation 10-25% at 5 years, up to 43% at 10 years
amputation_rates.minor_amputation: Often precedes major - multiple toe/ray amputations common

factors_affecting_outcome.tobacco_use: Single most important determinant - any tobacco exposure worsens prognosis
factors_affecting_outcome.disease_extent: Upper and lower extremity involvement = worse prognosis
factors_affecting_outcome.age_at_onset: Earlier onset associated with more aggressive course

surgical_principles.timing: Delay amputation to allow collateral development if possible
surgical_principles.level_selection: Most distal viable level; may require staged amputations
surgical_principles.revascularization: Usually not possible due to distal vessel involvement
surgical_principles.sympathectomy: May reduce pain and improve healing potential

adjunctive_therapies.prostacyclin: Iloprost - improves ulcer healing, reduces rest pain
adjunctive_therapies.spinal_cord_stimulation: May reduce pain and improve limb salvage in selected patients
adjunctive_therapies.hyperbaric_oxygen: Limited evidence, used in some centers for wound healing

learning_objectives: Understand the relationship between tobacco use and amputation risk
Apply amputation-sparing strategies in Buerger disease
Counsel patients on the critical importance of complete smoking cessation
clinical_pearls: Smoking cessation is THE treatment - can reduce amputation rate to near zero
ALL tobacco products must be stopped - including smokeless tobacco and marijuana
Revascularization usually not possible due to distal small vessel involvement
Multiple minor amputations often precede major amputation
A single cigarette can reactivate disease and precipitate limb loss
Delay amputation when safe to allow collateral development
